content:
ry 16, 2014
												Part of me really wanted to like Takedown:RS, but not even an hour in, and I can't stand to engage in this... it's truly a broken game in terms of basic fps mechanics and things that most of us gamers simply take for granted. I love tactical shooters, but wow have they got some work to do on this title. The lack of any radar or standard crosshair is a huge problem, but I suppose that was their intention given the 'hardcore' nature of the game to begin with. Even still, it doesn't help matters. Furthermore, movement seems glitchy and don't even get me started on the 'run' and 'sprint' functions in this game... unreal. Careful, going down a set of stairs at the wrong angle could prove to be fatal. Fall damage is outrageous in this game. Enemy AI is everything from oblivious to fully aware, ready to flick shot you as you stealth your way towards them. Talk about rolling the dice on this one. That just about concludes my rant on this game. You'd be wise to save your money and pass on this. As a takeaway, I hope the developers get a better understanding of these issues and patch in some serious fixes as the game matures. Good luck and Godspeed! 2/5

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
17, 2014
												This game is a piece of utter garbage. AI is unbelieveably stupid, yet some how manages to slaughter you and your team instantly. They sniped me from 300 feet, with a submachine gun while I had heavy armor. There's no point in using silencers, they can see you and hear you no matter where you are, and they call every NPC on the map to you.Your teammates are the WORST. When you die, they stand still while they wait for you to transfer to one of them. That means when you're taking 5 seconds to take controll, the enemies have the time to kill everyone, AND THEY WILL. They also get in your way constantly.The AI sucks, you die with a single shot to the chest even in heavy armor, even from a pistol.The reload breaks, you have unlimited ammo, and the controls are garbage.This was released as a "finished" game, and I have played alphas that are better made than this trashy heap of freaking garbage. DO NOT BUY THIS GAME.

content:
15, 2014
												Where to begin...It's always a good sign when a game starts off with, "I really don't know where to begin with this game." I bought this game during a sale for right around $1 and thought I had stumbled onto a good deal. After all, a game with steam trading cards grants some merit, right? Wrong. There are sooo many things wrong with this game. The menus and options screens are difficult to maneuver and clunky, the AI in this game is terrible, and the half the time you have no idea what you should do. The game just throws you into the menu, not really forcing you into training or explaining how to maneuver the menus to change character class or loadout. Pretty much everything is trial and error, with the training (that I eventually completed) not really being helpful at all. I give this game 0 pieces of crap out of 5 gold stars.PLEASE PLEASE PLEASE DO NOT BUY THIS GAME! NO PRICE IS WORTH IT!

												I would usually take a chance like this to be ironic and sarcastic as possible. But not with this â¥â¥â¥â¥ing game. First off, I have only played this game for like fifteen minutes, and in throughout that entire experience, I wanted to put a bullet in my face after every thirty seconds. I bought a 4-pack of the game for my friends and I and thought "Why not?". However it was a huge â¥â¥â¥â¥ing mistake not to read the reviews. I got in the game with my friends and I, and my first thought was "Wow, walking feels kind of funky." So then I shot a simple bullet, but my gun didn't even have any firing animation. I just kept shooting bullets into a wall and I had no way to tell. But that was fine. I walked down literally one flight of steps, turned to the left, and died. I thought "Ok, he had the jump on me, I will be more aware next time." So, I respawned, and walked through a door. Then, a single AI turned around instantly, shot me twice, and killed me. So this game must have the AI of â¥â¥â¥â¥ing Far Cry 1 and combined with the difficulty of Dark Souls. Don't buy this game, yes, it is cheap, but I doubt .50 cents would be a fair deal for this â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥ hellhole.

content:
12, 2014
												A brilliantly hyped piece of complete garbage.  If you can manage to convince it to run, the prolonged character customization will trick you into believing this is actually a game.  It is not.  It is the distilled essence of failure, wrapped up in shiny labels and an appeal to an underserved market cynically crafted to to con as many people as possible out of their money before they have a chance to see it for themselves.  There is nothing good about it.  The AI is awful, the guns feel like Hasbro toys if they were dipped in molten lead instead of paint, and the graphics are somehow uglier than much older, theoretically less advanced games.  The only good thing about it is that it has the good grace to crash frequently, sparing the user from having to play more of it.  I pre-ordered it, played it, and then gave up and uninstalled it before forgetting about it until now, desperate not to remember this horrible product.  The only thing that could save it would be a refund.

content:
ry 5, 2014
												I backed this on Kickstarter two years ago (April 2012). It was launched in the last part of September 2013, with an average of 88 players online. Within a month, it dropped to about 16 players on average and is has been an average of 7 players ever since. according to Steamcharts[steamcharts.com].As of this writing, I just logged in to see if I could get a pick-up game (even though the game-play is rather buggy and miserable). What I found were two game modes with no servers and no players. I found one game mode, deathmatch, which had one twelve-player server . . . with zero players.It has the base components for a game that could be decent, with a whole lot of work, time, and many iterations. Unfortunately, with a player-base big enough to stuff in a phone booth, it is unlikely that anything is going to come of this game. Yet another regretted crowdfunding game project.Even if you're fine with significant bugs and brokenness, it is impossible to recommend something at any price that doesn't have anyone you can play the game with.

content:
er 27, 2013
												Let me try to give a balanced review:  some of the shooty gameplay is actually fun.  I came back to this for almost 15 hours because it was kind of fun to see if I could complete any of the missions despite...well.  The innumerable problems with the game.So, fun aside, I have no idea how Serellan took an existing game engine (Unreal?) and managed to make it do things like lose the connection to the host while playing SINGLE PLAYER or not have a working game browser until several patches in.  Extremely basic design decisions are poorly done:  how might you handle weapons loadouts?  Customize before each mission?  Not in this game!  You chose four loadouts from the main menu, differentiated only by their names, and then chose those by name (what did I make the Assault loadout again?) when going into a mission.  (EDIT 12/27:  oh joy!  You can edit the loadouts at the mission jump-off screen!  But you're still editing the four choices...then choosing one.........idiots...)  Your team members never changed weapons, so the one guy was always carrying a sniper rifle, even through urban hallways.  That might've mattered if the team AI did much more than absorb bullets or mutter things like "rounds downrange"--you have basically no control over them except to ask for them not to follow you, and even if they're supposed to sometimes their pathing will fail and they'll get stuck.  Ultimately, they were only useful as extra lives--except that their loadouts couldn't be customized, so eventually YOU were the idiot stuck with the sniper rifle while trying to do CQB.I wanted badly for this game to be good, but it wasn't.

Having worked with UE3 before their lack of knowledge on basic engine functions astounds me. Furthermore the game simply refuses to work in MP and SP will often disconnect you for no reason. This might be worth 5/10 if you can actually connect to play with friends otherwise i'm giving this 1/10 for actually being able to run but other than that this is a game in pre-alpha state.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
er 10, 2013
												As a Reviewer I try my hardest to find the good things about any game, wether it be good, or bad, and try to be as fair, rational,  intellectual, and informative as possible, while trying to keep a fairly positive and upbeat demeanor in giving my critique.And after only a few hours of this game I can safely say, while it may not be as "Horrid" as most people would put it, as I have played WAAAAY worse, this game unfortunately sits at the kids table in consideration of the quality of this highly touted Tactical Shooter.I along with many others were expecting this game to be pretty cool, as it at least had some people who had worked on Ghost Recon 2 and Ghost Recon: Advanced Warfighter 1 and 2, so I of course thought "Wow this game has some talent behind it, it looks interesting, glad to see a methodical shooter instead of most of the action based nonsense we usually get."But sadly that was not the case.While it may have looked promising in it's preview stages, it just seems that the game never really left that phase.Were to begin? Well for starters, how about the fact that the game has â¥â¥â¥â¥-all in regards to PC Settings as most of them seemed to be lacking, especially  like the  Display Settings where there is no options other than, Screen resolution and graphics settings of :Low, Medium, and High.The controls are somewhat ehh...I mean the sensitivy for the mouse feels rather slow for a game that expects you to have the reflexes of that of a cheetah, even at full sensitivity. Leaning is rather useless as all it really does is bend side to side from the waist up instead of, you know, LEANING WITH YOR ENTIRE BODY, making looking around corners more of a hassle than it needs to,so I practically don't even use that feature at all. Weapon damage is rather inconsistent at times as at times 2-3 shots to the chest will be enough, while sometimes you can shoot point blank at someones chest with no armor, with BUCKSHOT, and they'll still keep chuggin.The disturbing absense of Squad Commands feels very wrong for a "Tactical Shooter". I mean Squad commands have been present in most if not all Tactical shooters, and no I don't count Halting Your Squad mates, and just saying random phrases like "Going on Offensive" or "Going on Defensive" as being as remotely helpful as it generally does nothing, hell even Ghost Recon: Future Soldier had Squad commands! And that was more of a action third person Shooter!And the above problems don't help when the AI is rather inconsistent...what do I mean by that you ask? Well when the Enemy is so stupid as to stare at a corner all day, looking in the absolute wrong direction they should logically expect you to be coming from, walking directly past you even when you are firing point blank in their face, to being so alert as to know that you were to come out through a door on a balcony after killing one of my squad mates on the bottom floor, shooting me in the face with disturbingly accurate accuracy in one shot, when logically there was no reason to know I was going to come out from there, HELL, sometimes the enemies will know I'm behind a door, even though they didn't hear me, or see me going through the door yet...seriously are some of the enemies psychic?The same also applies to your squad mates too. If they aren't really hyper aware and getting really accurate shots killing the enemies really quickly, they are either NOT shooting the enemies and are just shouting that theres an enemy soldier coming right at them, while they are looking Straight at them, not firing a bullet, usually resulting in very crappy and hilariously awful deaths, or WORSE, getting you stuck in a corner, keeping you captive until you put a bullet in one of their skulls, which surprisingly they don't retaliate for.The Graphics is...Alright, it at least looks serviceable at High Setting, but the worst thing about the presentation has to be the animations...I mean, I get some serious X Operations vibes just looking at them walk, it's just un-natural.and after all that, was there anything good about this game...well, I liked the fact that you had to be mindful of how long your weapon is in consideration to the walls adding a layer of strategic thinking, but even with that...no, I have nothing really good to say about this game...The most cardinal sin about this game is that fact that this game was released in a very poor, and rather unfinished state. Like most people have said, it does feel like an early alpha state game...the lack of modes and maps should be an indication of that, and the fact that Serrellan after all the money they got on kickstater, and then getting partnered with 505 games to puplish the game, and to just release the game, in THIS state, is just un-acceptable.It's so dissapointing to see such potential go to waste, as the guys at Serrellan obviously were proud of this game, and work was put into it.Like I said before, this game isn't as awful as some people make it to be, but would I say it's good, no...If I had to give a short review of this game, I would simply put: "Takedown: Red Sabre is like a dumb 4 year old eating crayons....it may seem adorable, but it doesn't cover up the fact it â¥â¥â¥â¥ it'self."

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
er 25, 2013
												Reading through Takedown: Red Sabre's Kickstarter page may give the impression that the game is a spiritual successor to classic PC shooters like Rainbow Six and SWAT4. Instead, like Tom Clancy's imagining of the submarine Red October, the threat of this game engages the player with little to no warning.The idea behind Takedown is a throwback to the classic era of PC tactical first-person shooters, but the desire to perform any form of tactic is tossed aside to make way for frustrating gameplay, unrealistic AI and disappointing physics. My first playthrough began with a member of my team relentlessly crouching and standing upright in an endless wave of teabagging while enemies sprayed bullets in our direction. Squadmates often stand in place like cardboard cutouts as enemies assault only to suddenly become active and return fire a few seconds after combat begins. I've had some enemies outright ignore me for nearly a minute after I accidentally sprint into them. Grenades bounce off of objects and sometimes launch across rooms as if they were thrown onto a trampoline, and enemies sometimes launch into the air or soar across a room when killed.Bad AI is Takedown's most crippling issue. Explosions don't tip them off to enemy presence. Flashbangs seem to be low-grade sparklers to them. They would rather stare at walls than pursue enemies and they often choose to shuffle around in a circle before engaging the player. Enemies can sometimes spot the player seemingly by looking through objects, yet they sometimes walk by a door where the player is in plain sight without a single reaction.The game's graphics are very rough, and the overall visuals look incomplete. Some weapons lack fire animations. Enemies look like an alpha build of characters from a mid-2000s game instead of a product from 2013. Anyone expecting top notch, or even acceptable, graphics from Takedown will be disappointed. Areas in a single mission often look recycled and uninspired. This can become especially troublesome if you become lost and can't remember what floor you're on. Most other shooter games would have the player press the âMâ key and dissolve the confusion, but there is no key to bring up a map in Takedown.Stage objectives are challenging and fun to attempt, but the frustration from bad AI and no map assistance kills the mood. Some objectives like âdestroy PC disk drivesâ are entirely too obscure. I discovered how to complete this objective by aimlessly firing in an office for no reason and struck a PC tower by accident. A room filled with large, standup computers was introduced before the office room was, so I was frantically trying to discover how to destroy these disk drives. The player normally interacts with objectives by holding the shift key, so changes in how objectives are completed introduced a great deal of confusion.Players may choose to customize layouts in order to choose primary and secondary weapons, grenades and breach charges; but customization often yields little change. I never felt like using a different weapon mattered much. The true difference came when I chose scopes over red sights, but I abandoned worrying about either after shooting enemies spot on in the abdomen only to have them scurry away unscathed and aimlessly charge up and down flights of stairs. Flashbang grenades leave enemies unharmed and hardly alert. Nearby explosions from frag grenades resulted in enemies staying in the same position, admiring the walls that enemies often stare at rather than reacting like a person would.Takedown offers Mission, Bomb Disarm and Tango Hunt modes of play. Bomb Disarm and Tango Hunt could arguably be more enjoyable than Mission, but the same issues haunt these alternate modes of play. These modes are made worse than Mission because a player's squad is reduced to one. It then becomes quicker to be killed, quicker to be overwhelmed by several bad guys so one random shot can instantly kill the player, and quicker to realize that the noise suppressor accessory for the weapons is garbage. If the idea behind Takedown is to be a spiritual successor to old games like Rainbow Six or other tactical, team-based shooters, then the idea of reducing a team to one to defuse bombs or to take out an enemy team is absolutely befuddling.Takedown: Red Sabre is a good concept's stage show of poor execution. The project's potential can certainly be felt and understood, but the likeliness of such potential surfacing â even through patches â is low. To call the Takedown project lazy would be harsh, but it wouldn't be inaccurate. The goals for this project were laid out in the open both in the Kickstarter campaign and on the game's official website, but very little victory can be tasted in this final product. Couple a disappointing experience with a $14.99 price tag, and you have arguably the most disappointing video game to be funded by a Kickstarter campaign.

content:
ry 17, 2016
Short ReviewA supposed comeback for the tactical shooting genre, Takedown: Red Sabre passes selection and completed his training courses, yet when it came to his first real mission, he floppedâ¦ Big time.Pretty much the bare basics of a tactical shooter. Awkward menu, horrible AI, mediocre game mechanics and glitches abound. But decent graphics and great level design.Kiddie Steam reviewer verdict: âchnged gun. started game. gun didnât change. Wnt back. changed gun. game still dusnt register change. carried on. ai squad gt stuck in door. Saw enemy across map with back turned. He turn round and killed me in half a second. Tried multiplayer. Uinable to connect 2 any server. 4/10 wud disconnect agen.âLong ReviewItâs no secret that games these days are all about your waist high walls, linear objectives and regenerating health. Answering the cry of help from the tactical gaming community, a few industry veterans (whoâs work involves that of Ghost Recon, SWAT and Halo) stepped up to the call and decided to create their very own game to resurrect this dying genre. GraphicsThe graphics range from excellent to quite poor. The environment textures look absolutely fantastic and whilst a bit too clean and sterile, offer a pleasing amount of colours and contrasts that make it an absolute shame you have to shoot up the place. Itâs a shame thereâs no peaceful mode as I would have loved to explore the excellently crafted map.The character models look fantastic! Boasting high polys and great texture work, each character looks like a real life operative whoâs been kidnapped and transported into the Unreal engine (bless their poor souls). The character and model artists really know what theyâre doing with this one. Itâs a shame that characters move like theyâre made out of wood and lack any idle animation, resulting in a game of musical statues. I donât even know if they can blink.On the downside, the weapon and first person view-models look like they were pulled from a game 5 years ago. Much lower poly than youâd expect so appear rigid and angular, plus they also house a number of bad faces that reflect light at odd angles. When you have a stunning environment with life-like character models, but have to stare at your blocky arms and firearm that looks like it was made out of tin foil, itâs pretty jarring to say the least.SoundThe music is pretty good, definitely sets the mood with its militaristic theme. Whilst there isnât a wealth load of tracks, theyâre all done to great effect and tie in well with what youâd expect from a tactical shooter.As for in game sound, well there isnât much to talk about. Everything seems eerily quiet and doors opening, soldiers screaming, spouts of gunfire is all youâre pretty much going to get. Whilst the guns sound ok, they sure sound generic and lack that looping variation youâd expect from games like Rainbow Six or Ghost Recon.GameplayTakedown: Red Sabre has come a long way since itâs behemoth of a disaster at launch, but sadly itâs still a sordid buggy shell of a game.The menu is basic but seems glitchy at times. Often Iâd try to change my equipment, only for it to not register until I realised you have to click on the kit name (recon, assault, etc), then click âsave loadoutâ then click back. At least I think thatâs how I did it.Your AI squad waddles behind you like a group of duck, refusing to follow any sort of tactical formation, either choosing to form a conga line or dancing all over the place like frightened cockroaches in a matchbox. Very much like your first puppy, outsides of asking them to follow, sit, attack or stay quiet, thereâs pretty much no other use for them except extra lives should you bite the dusts. Moreover, when you get killed in a doorway, they enjoy running straight into the doorway and getting capped themselves.The enemy AI is just as bad. Running around like headless chickens, staring at a shiny wall instead of that door you just blown openâ¦ then managing to do a 180 spin and headshot you from across the other side of the map in about 0.23 seconds. Cheap.I have sadly never ever been able to participate in a multiplayer match, thanks to a wide range of âconnection problemsâ and error messages. Having played prior to writing this review, Iâm still getting unable to connect to server messages and I still cannot get a LAN game to run. Movement is a little odd as you seem to slide everywhere. You canât lean very far nor move and lean (which apparently is due to quote âThe realistic nature of the gameâ) even though you could do so in most other tactical shooters.Asides from the terrible AI and connection issues, there is a game here, itâs just very barren. It has its moments of enjoyment and if you can accept the complete package for what it is, itâs not the end of the world. If somehow you manage to win the lottery and spot a pig flying in the air at the same time, get the multiplayer to work (if it still does) and playing with other people should make the game more enjoyable.Final WordsTakedown: Red Sabre is a huge disappointment. Whilst itâs not an absolutely terrible game, itâs far far from a good one either. Having trashed the game on a public article and being called out for having inaccurate info then told by the game developer that many problems have been solved, bottom line is many many problems still remain. Whereâs my multiplayer?As for the company behind Takedown: Red Sabre, theyâre making a new tactical shooter called Epsilon. The question is, should you support them? I think so!Theyâve seemed to have learned from their mistakes and putting all efforts into their new title. Iâve gotten my hands on the alpha and for the price of a 6â Subway, itâs given me great bang for the buck. Still, a few bad lemons are bound to pop up in a box every now and then, so I urge you to check Epsilon out.

content:
er 25, 2013
												No, no, no. Please god no, not another five minutes of this game. THis game is so utterly appaling so smug in it's own failure that it needs to be taken down from Steam.But first let me spin you a little fable.Once upon a time there was a bloke named wolfthing, he had enjoyed one or two of the Rainbow Six Vegas games when he was younger but felt things were missing, like I dunno, TACTICS. Then he learned about SWAT 4 and this made Wolfthing happy, sadly it's not available for legitimate digital download anywhere and as Wolfthing was screwed over by pirates once, he won't pirate it. In his brooding he discovered Takedown: Red sabre and apparently so did one of his friends, who gifted him the game, Wolfthing was happy. Until he pressed Play. After a good 20 minutes of online shennanigins and about 15 of single player crap he quit the game and uninstalled it, creating a new category in his library marked "Horrible, So Horrible"Now that the scene is set, let me open with this.THIS GAME IS COMPLETE AND UTTER â¥â¥â¥â¥ FOR THE LOVE OF GODDONOTBUYITSo about 3 minutes after clicking play I have some issues already, the menu is â¥â¥â¥â¥, like worse than cheap console port â¥â¥â¥â¥, the options aren't the worst I've seen but they leave much to be desired. So I go to join my buddy and I can't. Eventually we find eachother on a public server. Now begins my 20 minutes of online play. I think it's best to describe my thoughts at the time rather than attempt to actually review this.Ok these controls are pretty slow, I guess it is tactical. Oh look I can open doors, but all the rooms are copy pasted, I haven't seen anyone yet, oh hey a bad guy no that's just my reflection, well this is boring, I'm out, peace.Yeah, pretty bad, the single player is much the same except the enemy AI sucks â¥â¥â¥ for a living, it takes a good 2 seconds at least for it to react and any retard can react to him in that time, they never surrender and have deadeye aim when they finally do wake up, meaning you will be insta-killed. Speaking of killed I suppose I should point out the game's only good feature and elaborate on it so I seem fair, when you die to switch to one of your squadmates, it's a brilliant idea and I can't remember PLAYING another game that did it, although I think one of the Brothers in Arms games did. It's great if you need to speedrun a level in order to get through a â¥â¥â¥â¥ game as fast as possible but in the end I gave up anyway.The story isn't a story it's a set up, and it works fine. You are a squad of a special forces division of a morally ambigous private military corporation. Basically people hire you to go in and shoot the bad guys before the Police get there and find the Illegal weapons you've been developing for sale to Private states, or the Government as the case may be. And this works fine, it means the game can skip some corners on the whole protocol thing that the SWAT games did. It does mean however with it's gritty black ops feel, you ask yourself why is there an army of deadeye terrorists (Who are apparently just some kind of Pro-humanity protest group in one mission) and noone is taking precautions to stop them?Sadly the game missed out on some base management stuff which I feel would've been kind of cool, having to manage staff, equiipment, the Public opinion, your secrecy and your profit, but that would've required extra work.Work is something the devs seem to have a paralysing fear of as they have released an unfinished game claiming it finished. It's not even a beta it's a â¥â¥â¥â¥ing dev-build they released at 0.8914 or whatever the â¥â¥â¥â¥ it is.Seriously don't buy this game, it's â¥â¥â¥â¥ on frozen â¥â¥â¥â¥ pie. I couldn't even play it for an hour. I don't really like scores in reviews but I'd give this one 0/10 and then add a million zeroes to the 10. Then triple it.

content:
ry 1
												Wow, here's my thoughts on Takedown...First off, key binding is broken.  I always assign my Tab key to reload function in every FPS game. But for some stupid reason, the Tab key is permafixed to console or chat in this one.  That's a deal breaker for me.  Secondly, the lean function appears to be broken. You should be able to stay in that position as you strafe, but you can't, even when you change the toggle in the settings.  Weird.  The gameplay itself was mediocre, nothing really stood out for me. Most everything seemed to be worse than Rainbow Six 3. It kind of a had a similiar feel to that game but everything felt dumber somehow, like I was playing a poor immitation of that game.  If it weren't for the poor controls, I might play around with this more. Overall the game feels very unpolished and unfinished.  Other than being curious masochist (like I was) or as a joke, I can't think of any good reason to play this. Every tactical shooter I've ever played before is better than this.

content:
, 2014
												EDIT: Decided to reinstall after what.. a year? Still awful. Avoid like the plague, seriously.Takedown: Red Sabre is.. painful.It fails as a tactical shooter. Planning is non-existent, there's no map in the briefing and no ingame map. There are no squad commands past "wait" and "follow". Your AI companions are basically extra lives for when you inevitably die. Flashbangs either don't work, or they blind you through a wall. There are no smoke grenades, or thermal goggles, so you're extremely limited in your options. Firefights boil down to edging around a corner, crouched and aiming, hoping you see the other guy first. Hardcore? Maybe. Tactical? Not a chance.

												This game has some potential but suffers severly from a few issues, namely:a) AI that is, at the same time, beyond stupid and annoyingly precise in it's shooting. Bad guys go from not seeing you at all to sniping you with a slingshot from across the map. Oh, and they take out the entire rest of your idiot squadmates before you can even switch characters. Which leads me to...b) No squadmate commands. Horridly annoying with the AI as completely mentally handicapped as it is in this game. This means you can't even use your blind/deaf/can't hit â¥â¥â¥â¥ squadmates at scout fodder. It also makes any kind of tactics like what you might be used to in Raven Shield completely impossible.c) Horrid interface design. It's completely unintuitive and doesn't flow.d) Nagging Issues: Here's one -every single door on every map starts "open". Minor in the grand scheme of things but annoying combined with a and b above when a hostile snipes you through 5 bulkheads or doors that would otherwise be closed. It's worth mentioning because it demonstrates the complete lack of polish on this game, and this isn't the only example I could have picked.e) There are other numerous issues that individually aren't huge but combined make for a frustrating experience.f) The developer doesn't seem interested in addressing player concerns. For the longest time I remember every complaint was responded with "Due to the hardcore nature of the game...". It was used as an excuse for exceptional game-breaking bugs (like the aforementioned horrible AI). The map design, overall, I thought was decent even if it feels a bit sparse or dated. A few of them are good enough I'd love to play them in Raven Shield. Frankly though this game just isn't worth it, and the developer doesn't seem interested in fixing it. This game is simply incomplete. I haven't dumped a lot of time into it and I have zero desire to bother again. While it has the potential to be pretty awesome at the moment it offers nothing you can't get elseware.

content:
ry 12, 2014
												This game was not worth 1.50. I should have never sold my cards to buy this game, it's not even a real tactical shooter. It's a slow paced shooter with several tactical elements, like.... walking very slowly.There is no fluid door opening, and if you open a door, you are more than likely going to die unless you place yourself at a wall. The options for this game are absolutely horrid. At max sensitivity, I still feel incredibly sluggish, making me want to throw up. Literally. The AI are as dumb as bricks, but they have an insanely fast reaction time ( wut? ).Occasionally, you'll be able to kill 20 enemies with ease, due to how stupid they are, but sometimes, you will be insta-killed by the game by an enemy who will use only about 0.2 seconds to shoot you. This is coming from someone who has fast reflexes and good aim. Not to mention, when you do actually get shot at, you will shot in the head. This happens 90% of the time and it makes the medium and heavy armor types very useless.The equipment options in the game are very basic, you get a frag grenade, a flash grenade, and a breach charge. The flashbang usually doesn't work, as terrorists seem to be completely normal ( By shooting me in the head ).They don't retreat from frag grenades, oddly enough... But the grenade physics make them feel like rubber balls.Breach charges are generally useless, as the AI will either open the door on you as soon as you put the charge there, or... There won't be anyone in the room.The mission variety in the game is pretty awful. There's only about 5 different missions, and this game was released several months ago. The community is either non-existant, or extremely stupid TKing trolls. You get 1 of the 2.The friendly AI is extremely stupid, worse than the enemy. You get terrible command options over them, and you are unable to seperate them and tactically manage them. You can tell them to follow you or watch a certain area, which barely works. You can't have 2 guys watch the door and have your sniper on the roof, because there is no way to tell them to get into a specific location.The weapons and damage in this game are REALLY weird. For a tactical game, it's weird how you don't even have to aim to accurately hit a target. Aiming is useless in CQC, you have a better chance to charge and strafe. And when you do aim, you can literally strafe left and right ( ADAD Spam ) and dodge most bullets. Except from the guy who instantly headshots you. Don't put weapons into full auto, just put your weapon in single shot and click as fast as you can. You can get much better accuracy and less recoil, while killing targets in 1-3 hits.The enemy AI in this game is really immersion breaking. ( If you wanted that kind of thing ).They seem to charge at you DIRECTLY ( Not heading towards cover ) or, they run away from you and do a 180 and headshot you, then retreat again into a random corner.The AI doesn't patrol around an area, engage in conversation with other AI, or do anything.Their only goal is to wait for you and to kill you. Being stealthy in this game has no benefit, most of them will somehow know where you are anyways, and then instantly headshot you. Surviving a bullet is rare, especially since armor isn't protective.(RECAP)There isn't a real story in the game, so that's a negative.No planning mode. A minus on the 'tactical' side of things.No advanced room clearing tactics. Just open and peek in until everyone is dead.Extreme lack of AI commands.Dead Community, about 40 players at MOST. I'm pretty sure Star Wars: Battlefront 2 has 180 players at most. Which is extremely sad.Extremely sluggish controls, including mouse sensitvity.Extremely barebones options menu. Extremely barebones menu in general.Very slow-paced, but not tactical.Not fun, or engaging. Instead of being intense, this game is more than likely going to make you rage.Buggy. ( After several months )Huge lack of content.Terribad AI.Un-immersive. No cool features either, like a tactical map or an overhead picture you can draw on or a planning mode.Lack of customization. Pick your guns, what armor, what you want on your patch, and what equipment. That's it.Completely random crashing and connectivity issues.1/10    -At least they tried-                      Actually, I don't even know if they tried, they seemed quick to place the game on Xbox Arcade.I recommend that you buy Rainbow Six: Raven Shield instead of this garbage.It's a much older game, but it's also much more fun.Especially with friends, where as this game makes everyone just get angry at each other until everyone leaves.

content:
ry 16, 2014
												"Made by the guys who worked on Rainbow Six and Halo!"By who, the mail room guy at Bungie? If someone took my stapler, I'd probably torture them by making a â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥ game too.This game is â¥â¥â¥â¥ing disgusting to look at. I'm gonna do a name drop here: ever watch Lowtax and Shmorky? They look at â¥â¥â¥â¥-tastic Unity and gamemaker games. This is on par with one of those. How ANYONE could think these graphics were passable for 2013 is beyond my comprehension. On high, it looks like your average Unity game. On low, it looks like, well, this.


YouTubeâ¢ Video: Â 

			Views: 0		



This is made in Unreal Engine 3 by the way. The Ball looks a hundred times better than this ever will.Gameplay is bad. The guns feel weak, the movement is terrible (running is almost the exact same as walking, sprinting seems infinite.) The enemies next to one-shot you no matter the armor, your loadout doesn't matter whatsoever, and FALLING FIVE FEET CAN KILL YOU INSTANTLY. The enemy AI goes from full potato to half-potato. The controls are also incredibly bad, but that's not a surprise by now. I played this game for about 20 minutes (I sadly spent the rest of the time idling for the last card drop), and this is without a doubt the worst shooter I've ever played. Bar â¥â¥â¥â¥in' NONE. And I have NO CLUE what the hell the last paragraph means when it says "If you are a fan of old school shooters where thinking meant more than running and gunning or perks." No shooter I've ever played, run-n-gun or tactical, was EVER this bad. "Out Think The Enemy" my foot.If you want me to give you an actual score or TL;DR, let me put it into perspective for you. I got this game TODAY, when it was on sale for $1.50 USD. I bought Audiosurf for that exact price a couple years ago, and it is one of my favorite games. I bought Alpha Prime, a REALLY bad game for $1.25 USD, and even that game was enjoyable enough to last a whole run through. I got this game as a GIFT and I feel buyer's remorse. BUYER'S REMORSE FOR A FREE GAME. I pity anyone who bought this for the full price, pre-ordered it, or even bought it at all.Do not buy this game.

												This game was a lot harder than I thought.  Basically it was like real life: you get shot, you die.  Guess thats why this is a hardcore fps. Regardless, this game would be for some people, but it is just not for me as I flat out don't like hardcore fps games where you die this fast.Rating: 4.5

												It seemed to be a much older game than what I am used to. It did have quite a bit of potential and probably would've taken off if all of these other first person shooters hadn't brainwashed us with a "good" and "bad" perspective on games. This one digs more into the serious aspect of a game, the one that makes you think, because your movement speed is slowed down significantly compared to other games, and one bullet is all it takes to kill you. Now, none of this is to say it is a bad game, I just don't have the taste for it, however, if you like a game that has rather indecent graphics, slow and difficult controls, a very limited armory with absolutely no possibility of hand to hand combat due to the lack of a melee command, and absolutely no storyloine or unlockable items; I'd recommend this game to you. If you do not, I'd suggest a different game for you, because there is a reason there's no gameplay in the trailer...

content:
ry 11, 2014
												I downloaded this again after a huge patch promised to fix this game. It hasn't.It's still broken. It's still dumb. It's still infuriating. And you still can't even change video settings mid-game. Nope. Every U3 engine game has this basic, fundamental feature but not this game! Nope. Want to turn down some graphics (which you'll want to since this game is so badly optimized) then tough â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥s, because you'll have to end your game to do so. Not only that, but the graphics look ugly, both in terms of graphical fidelity and general art style that really show a real lack of flare or interest. Compare the locations here to classics such as SWAT 4 and it just doesn't compare at all,  and I have no problem at all with saying that SWAT 4 has better graphics than this. It does.The A.I. still flails wildly from jedi mind tricks to sheer, inane stupidity, with absolutely no happy middleground. Each map is either unbearably tough and unfinishable, or you steam roll opponents like they aren't even there.the guns are fine, they look like guns, I guess, so whatever. But honestly, how can you get gun models wrong in this day and age? That said, it's no Battlefield or CoD in terms of how nice they look really, so even in that area this title is just very generic.Being a massive SWAT 4 fan, I was super excited about this, but it's not even a patch on the classic. There's no hostages to speak of, your teammates are just cardboard cut outs to be mutilated by zen-like opponents, there's no atmosphere, no immersion factor, you never feel like a SWAT officer (or are these guys army guys? The game isn't even clear on that) Like a lot of people, I saw TotalBiscuits playthrough of this and was super excited. What I didn't realize is that playing the game for more than 30 minutes will tell you everything you need to know. This isn't the tactical shooter you're looking for. There's barely any room for tactical descision, as your thought process is usually "will the A.I. headshot me from miles away in this next room or will they stand there looking at the walls?"Don't play this, play SWAT 4 instead. It's an eight year old game with more replay value, realism, fear, tension and tactical thought than anything this game has to offer.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
2014
												Don't! Just don't!I too wanted to like this game.. But didn't.Menu/lobbyOhhh Boy!The menues were the first alarm bell. Controls in the menues and lobby are clunky. Clearly aimed at the console crowd.There are no drop-down boxes for selection and overview of your options, and the menu graphics are.. well.. outdated is a nice way to put it.But to hell with menues if the game is good.But notice, there is no where to select enemy difficulty.. More on that below.Single-Player/AIAs already stated by others, the AI is...... well.. Frustrating is a nice way to put it.The enemies are super-human.. the AI squad mates, not so much.Example: AI squad mate crouches in the open and just looks at an enemy while I franticly try to shoot the â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥, and he me. Even after a reload, my 'friend' was still hesitant to shoot the terrorist.Another example: Sneaking down a corridor, a squad mate calls out, enemy spotted. I look left, I look right.. Nothing. No enemies. Then I hear the shot and the 'man down' message. Turns out, an enemy had moved up behind us. My squad mates spotted him as the proffesionals they are.. but.. decided he wasn't worth shooting at.Most of the time, though, the AI enemies will simply shoot you before you get a chance to spot them, so no worries.To put this in contrast, I enjoyed Rainbow Six 3. The AI was challenging, but the squad mates were dependable.Multi-playerSorry, I couldn't be bothered.Weapons, outfits and grenadesGrenades are weird: I threw a grenade at an enemy, but one of my AI squad mates walked in front of me and the grenade bounced back from his head.........Also tried throwing a grenade into a room where an enemy was waiting to ambush me. No explosion ensued, so apparently the grenade just vanished.The emphasis on realistic weapon modeling is a joke. The military trained me to fire a â¥â¥â¥â¥-poor SMG at targets 100 yards away.. and hit. http://www.thm-online.dk/public/billeder/genstande/1500-1599/b_1524_s.jpg <--- The SMG in question.In contrast, the 'proffesional' soldiers portraied in this game can't hit a stationary enemy.. from a stationary crouch.. with a holographic sight.. at 30-40 yards.The enemy advanced, and at less than 10 yards, more like 5, I finally managed to score a hit.. Not by carefull aiming, as I had done up to this point, but by spraying an entire magazine at his center body mass.Also, forget anything about bigger weapons and more powerfull sighting systems in single player, as you will always be leading your team. I decided not to try multi-player, so I have no idea if they are actually usefull there.I only tried a few weapons, but I noticed that the Steyr SMG, which should be awesome at this stuff; I've fired the Steyr Assault Rifle, and it's magnificent... The Steyr SMG in this game is crap. Horrible accuracy and control.For some reason, all the weapons use silencers by default, but this is worthless, as the enemies apparently can hear silenced weapons through several concrete walls.Weapon recoil is hillarious. Muzzle travel is comparable to firing an LMG from a standing position. Nuff said.You got a selection of armor, but I found that only the heaviest armor was usefull. The restrictions on wearing the biggest armor is not really that big, but being able to survive a few hits from the OP AI enemies is worth everything.Movement and controlI appreciate the effort to limit player mobility. However, there is a fine line between limited mobility and useless mobility.You can sprint. You can walk.. and you can sneak. Fairly standard. However, even at less than 10 yards, you have little chance of hitting anything if you as much as sneak, let alone walk around. I found that there was no such thing as hitting anything while on the move. So move-stop-aim-shoot became standard.One good thing has been implemented. You can turn on your flashlight and use the light as an aiming cone. Much like the proffesionals do. This lets you hit things in close quarters without actually aiming through the sight.As a nod to other tactical shooters, you can lean to a side. The first-person view effect being that the screen tilts a bit and your view moves a hairline fracture to the side. However, you CANNOT move while leaning, so if you want to take the smart option at doors, you will learn a new, weird dance of getting in position, leaning.. looking at the doorframe still.. un-lean.. move.. lean.. still looking at the door frame.. unlean.. move.. Ohhh, the enemy in the room just shot you.This should have been an awesome mechanic, but I decided real early to just forget about it.And lastly, speaking of moving, while you have been limited by the devs to how fast and agile you can move, the enemies have no such problems. Often running or dashing through rooms, then stopping bone-snappingly fast and firing off one round that hits you straight in the face.The resultThis game has done one thing right.The devs have reminded me that, Counter-Strike wasn't that bad a game after all, and maybe I should download it again and play it a bit.I know I paid â¬1.24 for this game.. but I really want my money back, not to mention the hour or so I spend playing it.So don't.. Just don't..

content:
3, 2014
												Takedown is a mess, but I've enjoyed the game nevertheless. It's glitchy as hell, and the netcode is unreliable, but when I have played with friends online I've had fun.It's a barebones experience. Do not expect a planning stage, or any team AI control beyond hold/follow commands and basic rules of engagement modification. The campaign is also short, and somewhat disjointed.The fact of the matter is that this game was obviously in an Early Access state upon release (The install directory of the game even lists it as "Takedown Red Sabre Early Access"), and wasn't listed as such in the store. That was enough to deal a severe blow to what could have been a pretty decent little tactical shooter.At this point, while I hope the developers will continue fixing and improving on their design, there's little incentive for 505 Games, the publisher, to fund them to do so.Again, the whole situation is a mess, but as much as part of me wants to dismiss it wholesale, I can't say I hate the game.It's brutal and unforgiving in the same way the old Rainbow Six games were, which is bound to be offputting to some people, but scratches an itch most shooters don't for me right now.Shots can kill or seriously injure you very quickly, and there is no way to recover health.The AI opponents have moments of startling cleverness, though most of the times they drop you will be due to not cursoring over them fast enough to evade their sometimes exceptionally quick and accurate weapons fire. There's a tenseness to the action that would be lost if the damage model and AI were more forgiving.The map designs are open and interesting, each one providing you with two potential "insertion points" which determine where you start. Some of the design is actually fairly visually attractive, though strange things like reflections that don't actually reflect the environment in a coherent way can slightly mar the experience. (Particularly in the "HQ" level.)Despite there being numerous doors on most maps that are purely decorative and don't open, there's a refreshing amount of freedom to how you approach each mission. The nonlinearity also scratches an itch I haven't had many first-person games reach recently. This isn't always player-friendly design in the sense of providing easy and obvious ways to progress, but I'm not sure this is a situation where one can have their cake and eat it too.HUD is rather minimal, and they go so far as to strip you of a crosshair. You can aim down sights, but that slows your movement. Recoil is extremely noticeable on most weapons, and really needs to be minded in combat.These are traits that add interest to me, but could be deal breakers for some.What's most likely to bother people though, and rightly so, is that the game simply isn't finished. It's glitchy to the point that sometimes something as simple as switching weapons will lock you into a selection, leaving you twiddling your thumbs when the grenade slot you locked into runs out of ammo. Menus are glitchy and need to be minded, sometimes forgetting loadout changes (particularly the addition/removal of silencers). It's missing features as simple as text chat in game lobbies.Despite the fact that I myself have found enjoyment in the game, I can't bring myself to recommend anyone spend $14.99 on it - especially not when Rainbow Six 3 Gold, which is $5 cheaper, scratches all of the same gaming itches and has far more polish, depth, and content. That said, Rainbow Six 3 is more than ten years old and there have been too few games like it on the market since its release. This is a genre and style of gameplay that needs preserving, but Takedown just isn't offering enough.(As Serellan updates this title, assuming they do, I will update this review. As of the time of this writing, the last update was February 6th, 2014.)

content:
ry 12, 2014
												This game was not worth 1.50. I should have never sold my cards to buy this game, it's not even a real tactical shooter. It's a slow paced shooter with several tactical elements, like.... walking very slowly.There is no fluid door opening, and if you open a door, you are more than likely going to die unless you place yourself at a wall. The options for this game are absolutely horrid. At max sensitivity, I still feel incredibly sluggish, making me want to throw up. Literally. The AI are as dumb as bricks, but they have an insanely fast reaction time ( wut? ).Occasionally, you'll be able to kill 20 enemies with ease, due to how stupid they are, but sometimes, you will be insta-killed by the game by an enemy who will use only about 0.2 seconds to shoot you. This is coming from someone who has fast reflexes and good aim. Not to mention, when you do actually get shot at, you will shot in the head. This happens 90% of the time and it makes the medium and heavy armor types very useless.The equipment options in the game are very basic, you get a frag grenade, a flash grenade, and a breach charge. The flashbang usually doesn't work, as terrorists seem to be completely normal ( By shooting me in the head ).They don't retreat from frag grenades, oddly enough... But the grenade physics make them feel like rubber balls.Breach charges are generally useless, as the AI will either open the door on you as soon as you put the charge there, or... There won't be anyone in the room.The mission variety in the game is pretty awful. There's only about 5 different missions, and this game was released several months ago. The community is either non-existant, or extremely stupid TKing trolls. You get 1 of the 2.The friendly AI is extremely stupid, worse than the enemy. You get terrible command options over them, and you are unable to seperate them and tactically manage them. You can tell them to follow you or watch a certain area, which barely works. You can't have 2 guys watch the door and have your sniper on the roof, because there is no way to tell them to get into a specific location.The weapons and damage in this game are REALLY weird. For a tactical game, it's weird how you don't even have to aim to accurately hit a target. Aiming is useless in CQC, you have a better chance to charge and strafe. And when you do aim, you can literally strafe left and right ( ADAD Spam ) and dodge most bullets. Except from the guy who instantly headshots you. Don't put weapons into full auto, just put your weapon in single shot and click as fast as you can. You can get much better accuracy and less recoil, while killing targets in 1-3 hits.The enemy AI in this game is really immersion breaking. ( If you wanted that kind of thing ).They seem to charge at you DIRECTLY ( Not heading towards cover ) or, they run away from you and do a 180 and headshot you, then retreat again into a random corner.The AI doesn't patrol around an area, engage in conversation with other AI, or do anything.Their only goal is to wait for you and to kill you. Being stealthy in this game has no benefit, most of them will somehow know where you are anyways, and then instantly headshot you. Surviving a bullet is rare, especially since armor isn't protective.(RECAP)There isn't a real story in the game, so that's a negative.No planning mode. A minus on the 'tactical' side of things.No advanced room clearing tactics. Just open and peek in until everyone is dead.Extreme lack of AI commands.Dead Community, about 40 players at MOST. I'm pretty sure Star Wars: Battlefront 2 has 180 players at most. Which is extremely sad.Extremely sluggish controls, including mouse sensitvity.Extremely barebones options menu. Extremely barebones menu in general.Very slow-paced, but not tactical.Not fun, or engaging. Instead of being intense, this game is more than likely going to make you rage.Buggy. ( After several months )Huge lack of content.Terribad AI.Un-immersive. No cool features either, like a tactical map or an overhead picture you can draw on or a planning mode.Lack of customization. Pick your guns, what armor, what you want on your patch, and what equipment. That's it.Completely random crashing and connectivity issues.1/10    -At least they tried-                      Actually, I don't even know if they tried, they seemed quick to place the game on Xbox Arcade.I recommend that you buy Rainbow Six: Raven Shield instead of this garbage.It's a much older game, but it's also much more fun.Especially with friends, where as this game makes everyone just get angry at each other until everyone leaves.

It is insane the level of detail the developers have added to this mechanism.Map QualityThis game has one of the best graphical rendering systems i have ever used.  The maps are gorgeous and flaw free!  Each map was made to be a fully emmersed scenario where you and your squad will feel as if you are actually there.Enemy AIThe Enemy Ai is the only thing I have 1 issue with.  This issue is they are just way to realistic!  They seem to play as if they are real players and not AI!  They call out to eachother your position, they tactically flank and execute plays against you while you are trying to defuse the bombs!Overall! This game is a definite 10/10 and I would recommend it to everyone!Most realistic shooter I have ever played.

content:
ry 15, 2014
												Okay, I've put in a fair amount of time to this game, -90% off? FPS Game that is tactical? Sure! Bought 7 copies for 5 dollars, and got it to work as soon as i put it in, okay. The loadout is personally my favorite aspect of this game, you get to make your own loadout, to fit your personal standards, cool. But the game, is, TERRIBLE, first off, when you play the training, its basic, you already know how to fit this game, the controls are standard, but serve no purpose. When you play your first mission, you will know what I'm talking about. The AI is too smart, smarter than your highly trained SWAT team you have following you like mindless zombies. When they see a bad-guy, they say Tango Spotted, so I tell them to shoot it, they just look at it though. The enemy AI always knows where you are. Your only intel is what the game gives you. You spend more time getting killed by super buffed pirates than you do killing pirates that aren't trained. If you're going stealthy, you'd expect that they wouldn't know where you are. But really, all they do is aim at you, until you come into the direct line of sight, then they start running after you. Glass is bad for you, because you can't entirely see through it, but the enemy can, and shoot at you, killing you on the first hit. There are around 2-3 people that are programmed to look in a certain direction, and not staring at you the entire time. Your team is â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥, you cannot tell a single person what to do. You have a sniper, an assault, and a breach, you are supposed to be the recon, but what if you don't like that class? Your team will stare at a bad guy, but not fire. They do not know where a single person is, until the person shoots them in the head, with their 99.99% accuracy, while yours and your teammates accuracy is 80%. Your team is clunky, ending up alerting the enemy before you can scope out the map, because you cannot make them wear different armor, or armor fit for what you want to do. The mission always wants you to go steath, when the mission objectives call for action. Your team always has silencers, when you don't even need them. Now I'm getting started on multiplayer. Half the time, you're on the team with a prick, who only wants you to hate the game you payed for, it's not even free, so they kill you with their insta-kill guns, wearing huge-â¥â¥â¥ armor, so they kill the entire team before the game even really starts, then they kill themselves, because they're bored. Other than that the maps are too big for 6 on 6 team deathmatches. If you could have 12 people on each team, then it would be fair, and the match would be 90% more interesting, but it's full of boring experience. I was lucky to buy the game for less than a dollar, you, are not. If you really want this game, just message me and I'll send you a copy. But be warned, until the makers seriously patch this game. IT'S NOT WORTH IT. 2/10

content:
2014
												Takedown: Red Sabre is a first person shooter that markets itself as a tactical shooter using mechanics akin to Americas' Army or Counterstrike. It fails to achieve this, as it fails to achieve anything, this game can best be summarized as an unfinished product, which if it was in early access it would be perhaps excusable (but it is not). Even the directory folder states that it is an early build of the game, and it plays like one. I cannot under any circumstance or at any price recommend this unfinished product, all you are given is a very small handful of missions with broken AI/game mechanics which make the game ultimately unplayable. It isn't even worth it for the steam cards.

content:
ry 10, 2014
												Where do I start?  Off the bat, lets get this bit out of the way, yes this game is awful, in almost every way you can think of, and a few you haven't yet.  But despite that, on occasion when they let their guard down I manage to convince a few friends to shuffle (that's what you do in this game, you        shuffle, noisily) behind me in a few (you can only manage a few before you'd prefer to remove your own eyes rather than keep playing) games of the various coop missions.  Yet somewhere in there, and I can't quite put my finger on it, there's something I'm quite fond of in the game.I often think, that if you gave a turnip enough time, and a few beginners guide to Pascal lessons, this is exactly what they'd come up with.  You'll never understand it, but its amusing just the same.There is potential here, I believe there is  a need for such a game rite now, and you do get a sense of the innovative and exciting ideas that are fueling this game, they just don't come through yet.Do you buy it?  Of course.  I'd really like to see It grow,   Its not where it wants to be yet, but I'm sure Christian Allen and the team at Serellan will take it there.  Check out their site, they are indie game development team that really value their community and are listening.  This is why I'm continuing to support it.

content:
ber 14, 2014
												This has got to be the best and most realistic shooter I have ever played PERIOD.  11 out of 7.  6 stars.  3 Thumbs up.This game is not for casual scrubby COD players, this is for the more serious skilled players, no not players, shooters.  You will actually feel like you are a real member of a special tatics team.  You get to play by yourself, or with up to three other team mates, either other human players or AI who actually act as though they were really special ops not just random 9 year olds spraying down hallways.  So if you can manage to get three serious people together you can have a great time simulating a real special ops team or team in general.  The game is really well designed and also, I'm pretty sure I mentioned this already, it's also really realistic.  You can create up to four different classes or presets with different gear.  You can also pretty much customize anything you could ever want!  You can pick your primary weapon and a secondary.  Your primary will pretty much be any weapon you could ever want.  You got rifles, single shot, burst fire, AND fully automatic, you got shotguns, you got it all, but no silly rocketlaunchers or grenade launchers as those would be both unneccesary and unrealistic for the missions you would be taking part of.  Your secondary will usually be some sort of pistol or a light weapon.  On top of choosing your own weapons, you can also pick attachments like different ironsights/scopes, and if that wasn't enough, you can also select different ammo (yes it matters), so be sure to have the right ammo for the right mission.  Then you get different equipment you can bring, I'm not going to bother listing them all but you can choose from a large assortment of grenades, you got claymores, you got all tons of stuff it's like a terrorist's dream come true.  I almost forgot to mention this, but you can also pick different armour or protective equipment that actually effect your gameplay, like it will make it so you can't run as fast or for a long amount of time if you have heavier equipment.  On top of that, you can even put a nice little patch representing whatever country you want on your sleeve.Now when you got your presets set up, you can pick either Singleplayer or Multiplayer to try them out.  I don't really want to take up too much of your time talking about the amazing thing called multiplayer, so in this review I'm only going to talk about single player.  First of all you get to choose which type of mission you want to do, from tango hunt to bomb disarment.  You'll get your mission briefing at the start of the mission and you can pick an area for deployment.  After that it's the same deal as most of those "army" or "special forces" shooters (cod, moh, etc.), where you'll go through the mission, but it's not like them at all.  You don't have that ridiculous red border to show that you're dying, you'll actually feel like you're dying and then eventually if you don't start to get serious, you'll be dead.  You also won't be picking up any of those silly health packs or other  nonsense pick ups.  The only things you'll be picking up are guns from the people you kill.  The enemy AI is also not like other typical games, where they just always miss and are totally oblivious of your presence.  They will hear your gunshots, they will hear your footsteps, they will call for backup.  Unless you get with the program you will die.  I'm not going to ruin the suprise of what happens when you manage to beat a level, that's an experience you just have to experience yourself.Well this review for this great game was a bit longer than I inteded it to be so I'll stop soon.  I'm going to start capitalizing every letter now to put emphasis on my next sentences.  THIS GAME IS A MUST BUY GAME, IT IS PRETTY MUCH A STEAL TOO.  IT'S SOO CHEAP I DON'T KNOW WHY EVERYONE DOESN'T OWN THIS MASTERPIECE.  THIS GAME HAS IT ALL, GUNS, EXPLOSIONS, RADIOS.  I HONESTLY DON'T KNOW WHAT ELSE I COULD ASK FOR IN A GAME.  THIS IS THE MOST REALISTIC SHOOTING EXPERIENCE THAT YOU CAN POSSIBLE EXPERIENCE WITHOUT ACTUALLY BEING IN DANGER.  I CAN'T SAY THIS ENOUGH, THIS IS A  MUST BUY GAME !!!I'm pretty sure I forgot to mention some things, but I hope you get my point.

content:
ry 10, 2014
												New tactical shooter at a low price running on Unreal? Why is is so cheap?If I had to place a specific genre on the top of my list of games I want to play the most, it would have to be the "Sci-Fi Tatical Shooter" genre. While Stellar Marines isn't anywhere close to complete, I looked for something to challenge me in the mean time.At the end of the day, playing isn't good enough. There has to be a challenge, and that is what seems to separate the two major classes of modern gamers. Games used to make you rage to the point of throwing your machine out the window (and not due to bugs!). Takedown: Red Sabre returns to these roots for the most part, which is why it was hyped up at the start.So what about all the other reviews and metascore? Why are they giving the title a huge thumbs down? Well the key issue lays with release day. I had thought about purchasing the title on release day, but passed off wanting to ensure I wasn't wasting money on a buggy game. Good thing I did, bugs were everywhere in the game. People would disconnect from singleplayer games randomly, and the server browser didn't work. Rest assured most (if not all) release day bugs have been fixed.Being a "hardcore" tactical shooter, it's not easy to beat. Playing by yourself is quite a trick, so bring friends whenever possible.Speaking of friends -- to make the game enjoyable you should bring some. The game isn't VAC secured, and trolls will be in game sooner or later. Teamkilling seems to consist of a moral punishment, nothing more. There's no current system (2/10/2014) to get rid of them without knowing Unreal's console. An oversight for sure, mainly from the game being so cheap. And don't forget there's no private or password protected lobbies!The game isn't complete, and shouldn't be advertised as such. The AI is very hit-or-miss, having naturally deadly aim the moment you open the door, but then stare at you in other cases. Flashbangs don't interact how they should, as AI don't seem to be "flashed" when thrown. The AI also seem to be unaware of any sounds, but then can somehow know you are outside the door.Maps are well designed, modeled after real life places that a tactical team might find themselves in. The key part is that the levels don't lack in openness. You have to be naked out in the open sometime, proving to be an almost instant death if you don't play it right. Indoor environments react how they should, but door handling with latency can be an issue.Could the game be more? For sure and without a doubt. Examples would be finer tuning on the Kevlar or bullet resistant gear (like where on the body), a prone position, or even a true clip/magazine system (a big must for hardcore). However, the title has to clean up the AI. In it's current state, it's not really hardcore, but it's getting there. One way to clean the AI up would be to add group intelligence like that seen in Half Life 2. Squad tactics are shown on the human side of Takedown, but not on the AI side of things. It would be simple as adding code when an AI spots a human player, other AI join in the firefight. Just play the level called "Facility" on Co-op. You will see what I mean, the AI all act independently.So there you have it. All the issues but good positives as well. This review is kind of odd being price dependent. I purchased the title for about $1.79. At that cost, I would happily slap a 7 for title. At it's regular cost, 6.5. With the odd handling somehow working out to make a hard game, it certainly checks the "different" checkbox for me. Anyone that knows me well enough understands it's a key criteria to meet.6.5/10 - 7/10

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
ber 23, 2013
												Many people were thrilled when they heard they'd be getting a tactical shooter again in this day and age of action shooters like COD. The premise of tactical team-based combat ala SWAT and Rainbow Six is mouthwatering to any veteran team-player. With one of the key designers of the classic Rainbow Six games behind the helm it almost seemed too good to be true and unfortunately, it kind of is. First off i'll state the games has MUCH promise and the prospect of user generated content is fantastic, but the problem with Takedown is it lacks character and style its predecessors had. It feels very generic and lifeless plus the addition of serious network hiccups and server browser issues dosent help. If you played "Realistic Shooters" like Operation Flashpoint Dragon Rising, SWAT 4, or ANY of the 3 Rainbow Six games, you'll learn this game pales in comparison to those. It has a budget price but for that same price you can buy one of the games i just mentioned and they would be more worth the buck. All in all, the initial feeling for this game is disappointment, but only time will tell if the devs can somehow redeem these critical mistakes.

number of helpful: 7 of 12 people (58%) found this review helpful7 people found this review funny
content:
y 8
												When I first loaded up Takedown: Red Sabre I was at a loss for words. The game portrays realistic close quarter combat in ways never seen before. The sheer atmosphere of the game quite literally took my breath away, because it made me want to die.The game is broken in so many ways, that you find yourself trying to change your loadout to one of the four predefined setups, only to find yourself always playing with the same weapon.The AI will either be intent on looking at the same wall until they are inevitably killed, or they will pull a blindfolded 720 noscope as soon as they see an atom on your body.Suffice to say, the game is broken to the level where it becomes a joke to play, but that in itself results in a tonne of fun. For all it's flaws, I've never had as many laughs playing a supposedly "serious" game as I have playing Takedown: Red Sabre.

												Having played this after buying it for 79p (around $1/50 rublei) I can honestly say that I do not recommend this game to anyone. Ever. Even if it's free. There are several issues with the game and I am going to post a few:1. Lag. Everyone gets lag. It's terrible. However funny it is watching your team walk into walls it gets boring after a while.2. AI. The bots in this game are terrible. Team mates don't help you and enemies instantly kill you while they are facing into a wall.3. Shooting. You cannot kill anyone. Insane recoil and no weapon damage as well as inability to aim.4. Snails. You move like a snail.5. Feel. The menus are horrible. They don't work. You cannot change loadout for some reason. You cannot change settings during a game and they are very limited. The chat is horrible and messages disappear after 3 seconds. I am yet to find voice chat.6. Players. Barely anyone plays this and those who do hate it. End of.

content:
8, 2014
												I bought this game when it was 1 dollar and got so far around 2 hours of playing time on it. That's well worth 1 dollar in my opinion. But 5 dollars? Not so much.Now, if you are looking at it for the full price, which is 5 dollars, you should take your money elsewhere. This game was kickstarted and I was looking forward to an actual tactical shooter as everyone else was. The team behind this game were a good set of developers who everyone believed could make a really good tactical shooter that could compare to games like SWAT 4 or the old Rainbow Six games.What you get instead is a game that seems about 80% finished, with solid shooting mechanics but shoddy texture work and poor AI. The AI sometimes hear you through two walls but sometimes don't notice you when you are next to them. Doesn't make any sense. The online community for this game doesn't exist as everyone has jumped ship on this game. So you're stuck with the AI teammates who just get killed constantly.For a dollar, if you are interested in a tactical shooter that you'll probably play for a couple of hours, go for it. But if you are looking for a tactical shooter for 5 dollars, look elsewhere. You're just wasting your money here.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
ry 15, 2014
												I usually don't write reviews for games, especially if they're bad, but boy... Thankfully I got 2 copies for $1.50, so it's not that big of a loss. It provided me with a lot of laughs at just how bad this game is. It's like if Rainbow Six and Counter Strike were to have a child, this would be it. But the child would have such bad mental retardation that it would basically be a vegetable. To pu that into applicable terms, it has the "tactical" "gameplay" of Rainbow Six with the "style" of Counter Strike. They might have managed to emulate a visual style close to Counter Strike, but oh boy, they missed all of the functionality. How about the tactial gameplay of Rainbow Six? Nope. AI is too stupid when you're not shooting, and way too smart when you are. They run out into the open, or run away from you. Basically, this video sums it up just perfectly: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=v0_W4Oo8dEA Stay the hell away, I don't care how cheap it is, unless you want to just laugh at how bad it is. I guess for $1.50 that's okay. 10 minutes was plenty to see how horrible this game was and that I never want to play it again. Is there a way to delete a game from your Steam library...?

content:
14, 2014
												If you're looking for a modern tactical shooter... Look elsewhere, this is not it.It's not as bad as some of the other reviews make out... That's about the best I can say about it though, because in all fairness it's just not very good. It's just simply not good...It's a bit like playing the very first Rainbow Six game... Trouble is it looks like the very first Rainbow Six game, with less detail. Textures look like something from 15 or 20 years ago. Lighting is flat and lifeless. Shadows, what shadows?I can ignore bad graphics if the gameplay is good. Trouble is the gameplay in this is dull and uninspiring... Walk round a corner with Guy1, get shot in the head. Walk round the same corner with Guy2 and shoot the guy that shot Guy1, open a door and get shot in the head. Guy3 goes through the door, shoots the baddy that killed Guy2. A door across the corridor opens and Guy3 gets shot in the head. Guy4 meanwhile is stuck with his â¥â¥â¥ hanging out of a wall before the first corner. Because Guy4 is such a derp, he gets surrounded and then shot in the head...People go on about the AI being "too hard", yet I don't think they're as tough as the old school Rainbow Six AI... The AI can be punishing and difficult if your team make too much noise. It's the games one redeeming feature in my mind.When it's on sale at a Â£1 it's alright if you can get a couple of people together, but it wears thin quickly...TL/DR? If you're looking for a modern tactical shooter... Get Insurgency instead.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
ber 30, 2014
												This was supposed to be the great hero that would bring back hardcore tactical co-op first person shooting to the old farts like myself, who have been waiting for a successor to games like Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six 3 and SWAT 4. It held great promise and the developer spoke such sweet words, pouring honey on the ears of the people like me. Then it was released...At first it seemed like a game with some launch hick-ups and bugs. The basis was there for T:RS to take this not-so-well sought after throne, but every update was just making more and more of a mess. Then, not very long after release, they started to sell it for 1â¬ and gave all owners an extra copy to give away to unsuspecting enemies friends... which is kind of a clear sign that they threw in the towel and gave up on it.As said; the basic foundation is there; a hardcore, slow paced, co-op, tactical game... if you can get into it. It's hard enough to get a group to successfully join a server, but then you can't make that server private. The AI seems okay at first, but is actually bugged out like crap in a thunderstorm. The game freezes, the game rolls over like a dog without anyone commanding, the game just doesn't do what it's suppose to and does everything it's not suppose to. The only thing that worked from the get go; the in-game text-to-speech chat, they had removed in an update. First the maps were all too big, so you were running around searching for the last terrorist... then they made them smaller, but made them minimal.Nothing has gone right with Takedown: Red Sabre, and my kind (the hardcore co-op FPS:ers) had to look elsewhere. Fortunately we found Insurgency, which is a bloody good game; get that one instead!The only thing T:RS managed to do was to have our gaming group make sarcastic jokes about "...it's in the hardcore nature of the game." and "...this game is epic!" which were compliments once upon a time, but after the release and subsequent downfall of T:RS have now become the worst insults we can say about a game.It's all just really sad...
